text:
Rockland Ave., north side, 400 yards west of Manor Road, showing the Grote House. It is over one hundred years old and was originally the home of Colonel Richard Connor, where Aaron Burr made his last call. It was later occupied by Dr. Rotton. The house no longer appears on the 1917 map by Bromley.

April 19, 1911.

By Wm. T. Davis through P. L. Sperr.

Manor Road, west side, 500 yards north of Rockland Avenue and 225 feet back of the road. This house belonged to Dr. O. Rotton, according to Beers's maps of 1874 and 1887. In 1898 it was the Edward Hibberd home, and in 1907 the Fanny J. Byne's house (Robinson maps). In the far background, on the crest of the hill, are buildings of Sea View Hospital. Mr. Sperr states that the house was built be- tween 1850 and 1860.

1924

P. L. Sperr

Rockland Avenue, north side, between Manor Road and Forest Hill Road, showing Seaview Hospital, the New York City Farm Colony. Seaview Hospital is one of the largest tuberculosis hospitals in the world. The farm colony is used as an asylum for the aged.

April 25, 1929

P. L. Sperr

(1) Manor Road, west side, about 500 yards north of Rockland Avenue, showing the old Frech house, in the valley about 450 feet back of the road. P. L. Sperr states that the spring, in the foreground, is the largest on Staten Island.

February 12, 1927

P. L. Sperr

(2) A distant view of the Frech house as seen from Manor Road. In the background, on the hilltop, are buildings of Sea View Hospital.

May 1932

P. L. Sperr

(1) Manor Road, west side, about 500 yards north of Rockland Avenue, showing the old Frech house, in the valley about 450 feet back of the road. P. L. Sperr states that the spring, in the foreground, is the largest on Staten Island.

February 12, 1927

P. L. Sperr

(2) A distant view of the Frech house as seen from Manor Road. In the background, on the hilltop, are buildings of Sea View Hospital.

May 1932

P. L. Sperr

Rockland Avenue, north side, between Manor Road and Forest Hill Road, showing one of the new buildings of Sea View Hospital, built by the Works Progress Administration.

February, 1937

W. P. A. Photo
City Wide Project

Rockland Avenue, north side, between Manor Road and Forest Hill Avenue, showing W. P. A. workmen erecting a new building for Sea View Hospital.

February, 1937

W. P. A. Photo
City Wide Project
